Hello Delphi Chief, I started using GitHub and I want to upload my code there as I have seen thousands, but when I try to upload the following message appears: ‚ÄúYowza, that‚Äôs a lot of files. Try uploading fewer than 100 at a time.‚Äù Could someone explain to me how you upload files from WPILIB to your gits?

You don‚Äôt upload files. You create a repository on github and push your local repository to it.

Unfortunately, git has a medium-high learning curve even for the basics.

There is no shame in starting out with the github desktop app if the command line isn‚Äôt making sense.

I‚Äôll have to write at a later time, but there are also tons of video tutorials if you want to get started.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Git Version Control Introduction

Git is a Distributed Version Control System (VCS) created by Linus Torvalds, also known for creating and maintaining the Linux kernel. Version Control is a system for tracking changes of code for d...

Aaron_Li:

There is no shame in starting out with the github desktop app if the command line isn‚Äôt making sense.

There is no shame in using this ever. For some people the way the UI shows diffs instead of trying to use the clunkier cli diff tool is all the difference. People should use whatever they are most productive with.

I highly recommend the desktop tool for anyone just getting started with GitHub. If your team uses other Git servers or hosts their own GitLab you will have to learn the cli eventually or use an IDE/Code Editors built in VCS. VSCode is decent, but feels overwhelming when you first open it up.

I will say any professional should learn git cli to work both through a shell remotely, or on a headless machine locally (especially common in robotics).

kingc95:

instead of trying to use the clunkier cli diff tool

You could try using git difftool and git mergetool, which let you use a visual diff/merge tool like Meld.
